results.title: Dairy farming in the Alps
results.brief_description: Shows how people of an alpine village depend upon the making of Emmentaler cheese for their income.

results.title: Daily miracle
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how the newspaper “The West Australian” is set up and printed. The film shows all stages of production, from setting of type which is then checked in the reading room to the final printing on rolls which contain over 120 miles of newsprint. Demonstrates how a big newspaper works, and its reliance on other world sources of news.

results.title: Daily life of the Bozo people
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: A documentary account of a typical day for the Bozo tribe in Mali, West Africa. Environmental demands are met through a classic division of labour determined in large part by the annual fluctuations of the River Niger. Shows the people as they wash, weave, fish, cook and eat. Without narration - natural sounds only.

results.title: Daily bread
results.brief_description: Although Britain grows grain, most of the flour needed to make the bread which feeds the people of the British Isles is imported from overseas. This film follows the processes of manufacture from the time that the flour is unloaded in the ports until it leaves the baker’s van in the delivery-man’s basket.

results.title: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan
results.brief_description: Traces the early history of photography, concentrating on the achievements of Joseph Niepce, who in 1822 invented the first permanent photograph. Louis Daguerre, who in 1838, developed a process for recording photographs on polished metal plates is shown with other innovators in the field.

results.title: Dad's house, mum's house
results.brief_description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. The children may move back and forth between parents, or one parent may retain day-to-day care…its form varies from family to family. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.
results.description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. results.title: D.P.: Displaced Person
results.creator_credit: Barry Levinson, HTV and Alan Bridges
results.brief_description: Based on the story by Kurt Vonnegut Jnr, author of Breakfast of Champions and Slaughterhouse Five. It’s the aftermath of the world’s greatest war. Allied occupied Germany, ravaged and shamed in defeat, must now pick up the pieces. One of those pieces is a small black orphan boy named Tobias. Abandoned at a cold and dismal orphanage, he dreams - despite jeers from the other embittered children - of his courageous father’s return from war to claim him. When Tobias meets his first black man, he’s convinced the G.I. sergeant is the father of his dreams.

results.title: D.O.A = DOA
results.creator_credit: Leo Popkin, Cardinal Film and Rudolph Mate
results.brief_description: This fast paced exciting crime story was originally released as a B-movie filler but has, through the years, acquired a reputation as one of the most effective and most impressive of Hollywood film noir. Edmond O’Brien plays an insurance man, unsure about his life and his feelings for his girlfriend Paula (Pamela Britten), who on a weekend trip to San Francisco finds himself the victim of a bizarre poisoning. His attempts to unravel the mystery while counting down the clock to his death lead him to a reappreciation of his own life. Directed by Rudolph Mate who was the cinematographer for Carl Dreyer’s “The Passion of Joan of Arc” and “Vampyr”, the highly evocative cinematography, chilling musical score by Dimitri Tiomkin, and the desperate central performance by O’Brien all contribute to making this a truly suspenseful and dark piece of filmmaking.

results.title: D'artagnan's daughter = La Fille de d'Artagnan
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, Little Bear, TF-1 Film Productions and Bertrand Tavernier
results.brief_description: In this historical swashbuckling comedy/adventure set in France in 1654, a feisty young woman (Sophie Marceau), daughter of the famed swordsman D’Artagnan, cuts short her religious studies when she uncovers a plot to assassinate the young Louis XIV. Heading to Paris she persuades her father, now in retirement, and the three other original musketeers to fight alongside her to defend their country from the insurgent forces that threaten to throw the nation into disarray. A lush, lively film assuredly directed by Tavernier that pairs old-fashioned adventure with a contemporary knowing wit and a feminist sensibility. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Philippe Noiret, Claude Rich and Nils Tavernier.

results.title: Czechoslovakia: land and people
results.brief_description: Czechoslovakia is a country of two parts: Slovakia, a rugged mountainous land, and the Czech lands, a rich farming region with many industrial cities. With historical perspective we see the two regions as part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, then as a democracy after World War I, and finally as a Communist state.
